comments.commentBody: Didn't you answer your own question.  If people are "stupid" then don't they NEED protecting?  Or you'd rather they trip and fall so you can watch?

I live in and for 30 years worked for a city with a predominantly low-income, minority population.  Our demographic profile is similar to Baltimore's.  The whistle blowers at Wells Fargo provided evidence that the company's Baltimore branch set up a unit of mortgage peddlers specifically to prey upon minority residents using deceptive tactics, outright lies, high pressure, etc.  E-mail exchanges showed the derisive attitude of the company's reps toward their victims, and the pressure to sell ever more of a product that was designed to yield quick, short-term profits and then (financially) blow up and result in foreclosures.  The mortgage schemes of the last decade were the culmination of decades of capitalist fraud in the industry that greatly escalated in the financial environment that eventually imploded.  To blame the victims is reprehensible.

I'm not going to waste my time addressing the specifics of the author's comically transparent attempt to impugn Ms. Warren by frame the issue as one of "empire" building or bureaucratic rent seeking on her part (while studiously ignoring the rather larger emoluments driving the actions of the innocents populating the financial world of his fantasy) except to say that Mr. Cohan's description of a $500 million regulatory budget as an "expensive bureaucracy" or "empire" proves just how little credence we should give to his opinions. Why not put that number in context Mr. Cohan? Why not compare the size of the agency's budget to, say, the size of the GDP, to the size of the total federal budget or to the size of the losses incurred by homeowners or banks or taxpayers. Why not indeed.

An aspect that is never mentioned it that nearly all homeowners had LEGAL representation in the mortgage process. Therefore, why didn't their counsel ask for additional information if their clients did not understand fully what they were signing?

The real truth with mortgages is that the rules changed. In the past, potential homeowners felt that if they were approved for a mortgage, then they did not need to worry about meeting their obligations. However, driven by fees, FANNIE guarantees and the ability to sell off their mortgages, lending institutions started to approve everyone. Who is ultimately accountable - the person who signs the paper. Again, if they did not understand, ask counsel or don't sign.

If everything is really that complex then set standards - mortgage payments cannot be more than 35% last year's verifiable income over a 30 year period with a 20% down payment. That will put Ms. Warren out of business promptly and deservedly.

There is another option here not discussed.  How about having regulations than make the contract language understandable at a sixth grade reading level. Then, of the 10-40 pages needed to sell a house identify the few really potentially large concerns; say, a balloon payment, interest rate increase in the future, pre-payment penalty, etc., and require a special section in bold for these with separate signature.  But you don't have to outlaw balloon payments or indexed interest rates or pre-payment penalties, some people need and want these features....

William Cohan is one of the funniest comedians of our time.

I mean, he can't be serious, right?

Why is it that you wealthy, financial guru-types never (ever) take exception to the nefarious practices behind these maneuvers?  Why should credit card companies be allowed to raise the interest rate after entering in to the initial agreement with the consumer?   I'm sure it doesn't happen to you, but when a working class person decides to close a credit card account (by his own request), it adversely affects his credit rating.  Thus, we can't just keep changing CC companies willy-nilly to get the best "bargain."   I think you'll find the public becoming increasingly tired of the old "caveat emptor" routine.  Consumers would not need protection if there weren't so many companies trying to gut them.  Or, maybe you'll continue blaming the victims and apologizing for the predators.

Simply put: bankers are smarter than me. WAY smarter than me. I shouldn't have to be a mechanic to purchase a car that doesn't explode, and I shouldn't have to be a financial expert to get a mortgage that won't either. This should be basic.

Why shouldn't there be consumer protections? If businesses are not engaging in corrupt practices, they have nothing to fear from consumer protections. The fact is that business are against any protections because they want to keep up with their predatory practices, which are highly profitable to a few and devastating to the many. I want consumer protection. I have had no problems myself. However, the economy is in the tank. That is not good for me or most people. I do not want a repeat of this mess.

So many long comments, I'll be brief.  I want a level playing field.  That's it.  If folks make bad decisions, let 'em suffer.  $39 late fee charges?  While they're still raking in usurious interest charges?  Well, okay, but where are the credit card companies who are competing on price?   The credit card companies are colluding.  Level the playing field.

I agree with Cohan, and think the real agenda of this new consumer agency will be to crackdown on the payday or auto title loan industry because of the usurous interest rates they charge. Yet if you go into the offices of these companies, the interest rates are clearly posted in large figures. But do-gooders say consumers are being ripped off by these rates. I happen to agree with the do-gooders on the rip-off, but what right does the government have to interfere in a commerical transaction where all of the dangers are clearly stated. If people want to pay 360 percent interest rates on a loan, and the rate is clearly stated, what business is it for anyone to interfere in their decision. Yes, it is a very bad decision, but payday loans are popular. The same with the liar loans on houses. These people were speculators who knew what they were doing, and now should bear the consequences of their bad decisions. Our economy is wrecked because of all the foreclosures, yet Congress has rushed to set up a government agency that is created to protect them. So where do we go from here? Do we have government agencies created to protect stockholders from their stocks declining in value? Surely there are lousy executive decisions behind the decline of value of stocks, but the customers knew the risks and invested anyway because they concluded they might make big bucks from their actions.

This essay is off-base, starting with the title. By using the word "fallacy" you are accusing supporters of tighter financial regulation meant to protect consumers of being illogical. These are strong words, sir. Especially when your extremely short opinion piece lacks any nuance or logical defense of your own position. Instead you lean on hyperbole and hypotheticals. Your argument boils down to 'people make stupid decisions so let's refrain from doing anything.' That is how we got into this mess in the first place. Stricter financial regulation, especially in the area of mortgages and loans, is absolutely needed so we don't repeat the mistakes of recent history. Or have you forgotten already?

Mr. Cohan, you either have a been in a coma for the last decade or just came back from a very long sabbatical to a different planet! Either way you have a lot to catch up with on the way banks, credit companies, and many financial institutions have made it their primary business to cheat, mislead, entrap, and abuse their customers in every possible way, and call it "doing business" with a straight face! It's time somebody stood up to these predators and said "NO, you shall not ruin families and lives" with your unethical and ruthless ways! The budget you mention it is going to take to run this new bureau is nothing compared to what it can save the consumers over even a year! So please drop the act and let's do away with all the unnecessary theatrics...
The reason for such "protection" against peoples' studpidity is that it ends up costing everyone so much.

Look it's quite simple to understand why there are people that can't understand a contract, and more so, especially when it is purposely written to be complicated.
Only 65% of High School Graduates can apply for college entrance.
Of those 65% another 65% fail the minimum understanding of test questions. That leaves only 22.75% or 22 people per 100 student which have reading comprehension.

This was a study done by the University of ULA or SC a few years back.
Quote: "It is not that the average (student) doesn't know how to read, but the lack of understanding what they are reading".

These basic English comprehension tests, what do you think the failure rate would be on complicated legal language ?

It's an obvious fool who looks at our primary and secondary education systems in tatters in inner cities and thinks the products of those systems can understand convoluted and lengthy contracts. Besides, social pressure leads Americans to have them even if they're signing a deal with the devil. I assume Cohan is too well-informed to be ignorant of all this; so he's being disingenuous.

Moreover, the well-functioning of society is best served by having a centralized authority ensure that credit terms are fair. Usurers have no place in a vibrant democratic society, so governments do well to exclude them.

But the most outrageous thing here is that Cohan wants to paint bankers as the victims of dishonest borrowers. The bankers are the powerful, sophisticated, and well-educated bunch. If they're worried about dishonest applications, they have full powers to verify them before providing credit. The fact of the matter is that they were simply gambling that they could enforce the debts they led people into acquiring. I mean, what kind of banking system is it that pre-approves unemployed students for credit anyway? One that cries out for regulation. Simple as that.
God save us from people who think like Mr. Cohan.

“…one homeowner after another signed mortgage-loan documents that were filled with inaccurate information about his or her net worth, assets, salaries and ability…” and here I was thinking all this time that the tax returns and pay stubs, credit scores, and credit card statements were being looked at and verified and, using their training and professional expertise, lenders were “calculating” our “ability” (otherwise why bother?). Jokes on us, I guess. Obviously, the correct thing for us all to have done was to quit our jobs and get a real estate license and then go to banking school and then go to law school. Then we could have figured it out for ourselves and not have had to rely on the “integrity” of the lending “professional” (you know, like we go to medical school before getting that operation or dental school before deciding on the proper crown, and…). Yes, it’s obvious, all those people must have just been stupid and signed up for a loan that “could never be repaid “. That’s the only possible explanation. Right.

So clearly you would favor the alternative, which is much more stringent regulation on the business that provide these risky financial products?  Seems that your column would have been more productively spent expounding on your statement in the first paragraph that "Wall Street certainly needs some refor"

There shouldn't be any American women or men in Afghanistan, or Iraq. Right and left can argue about wasteful spending for healthcare reform, bank bailouts, education budgets, etc. In the end, this is the most wasteful thing this country has going for it, in terms of money and lives wasted and ruined ALL for empire.
WOW!  These are some of the best of our gender.  They are brave and kind.  Let's pray for their safety and honor them when they return.

This article could have been written in 1968. You've got the commanders not knowing what's going on with the troops. You've got confusion as to what the mission is. You've got naive schemes to win the hearts and minds. You've got the drugs. And of course you've got the dying.
When will we stop these crazy wars, and stop wasting lives of our brave soldiers, and the so called collateral other lives of living being? Ahem! Does Obama ever get to read these comments? Hello?

what you say against India, note that the President of India is a low caste woman, the most powerful figure in India is a catholic Italian woman (may be there is only one catholic Italian woman in India!!); the vice P{resident is a Muslim; the prime minister is a sikh (about 2% are Sikhs in India.  These people are all elected people aND DID NOT COME THROUGH ANY MILITARY DICTATORSHIP. India is still about 80% Hindu.  So, you see India is not only democratic but also the most tolerant society.  Unfortunately, it also tolerates corruption, filth etc.  But I would try to clean up all the corruption and filth and still praise India for what it is.

India - you have a bright future. Never mind the detractors of the world or the disappointment at your laggard and corrupt bureaucrats. Use this watershed moment to build transparent institutions, demand better governance of the nation right from the grassroots level and seriously criminalize tax evasion/corruption. Give careers in law, social sciences and non-IT engineering their due, to deal with their respective issues amidst the fast-growing economy. And last but not the least, raise civic consciousness among the masses and individual responsibility of the citizenry.
